articles.headline: Mobile Phones Become Essential Tool for Holiday Shopping
articles.snippet: Using powerful software applications on their smartphones, consumers can search for bargains across a range of retailers.
articles.abstract: Using powerful software applications on their smartphones, consumers can search for bargains across a range of retailers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The mobile phone is quickly becoming Santa’s biggest helper.

articles.headline: A Greek Bearing Promises
articles.snippet: Prime Minister George A. Papandreou has promised to reduce Greece’s budget deficit to 3 percent of G.D.P. by 2013, from an estimated 12 percent in 2010.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister George A. Papandreou has promised to reduce Greece’s budget deficit to 3 percent of G.D.P. by 2013, from an estimated 12 percent in 2010.
articles.lead_paragraph: People who lie to join a club may not prove to be very good members.

articles.headline: Nearing Arms Pact, U.S. and Russia Look Ahead
articles.snippet: The U.S. and Russia plan to start talks on whole categories of nuclear weapons never before subject to limits.
articles.abstract: The U.S. and Russia plan to start talks on whole categories of nuclear weapons never before subject to limits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Eight months, three presidential meetings, countless Geneva negotiating sessions and one missed deadline later, the United States and Russia appear close to agreement on a new arms control treaty that will reduce their strategic nuclear arsenals by at least one quarter.

articles.headline: Ernst to Pay the S.E.C. $8.5 Million
articles.snippet: The audit firm forced Bally Total Fitness to stop improper accounting practices, but didn’t make it admit to poor accounting in the past.
articles.abstract: The audit firm forced Bally Total Fitness to stop improper accounting practices, but didn’t make it admit to poor accounting in the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2002, worried about growing financial scandals, the audit firm of Ernst & Young set out to identify its riskiest clients and force them to comply with accounting rules. The effort backfired.

articles.headline: Muslims Say F.B.I. Tactics Sow Anger and Fear
articles.snippet: Muslim leaders say their relations with the F.B.I. have reached a low point in recent months.
articles.abstract: Muslim leaders say their relations with the F.B.I. have reached a low point in recent months.
articles.lead_paragraph: The anxiety and anger have been building all year. In March, a national coalition of Islamic organizations warned that it would cease cooperating with the F.B.I. unless the agency stopped infiltrating mosques and using “agents provocateurs to trap unsuspecting Muslim youth.”
articles.byline: By Paul Vitello and Kirk Semple

articles.headline: A Break at the Gas Pump
articles.snippet: Retailers might be emboldened by the recent trend in gas prices, but the numbers are much higher than a year ago and experts disagree about where prices are heading.
articles.abstract: Retailers might be emboldened by the recent trend in gas prices, but the numbers are much higher than a year ago and experts disagree about where prices are heading.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  This holiday season, consumers can expect a gift that should ease their burdens a bit: modestly lower gasoline prices.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: At Bank of America, a Chief Steps in Where Few Can
articles.snippet: Bank of America’s new chief, Brian Moynihan, in many ways has had a career of falling into bigger jobs at the bank when executives were fired or shunted aside.
articles.abstract: Bank of America’s new chief, Brian Moynihan, in many ways has had a career of falling into bigger jobs at the bank when executives were fired or shunted aside.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Bank of America scrambled this week to appoint a new chief executive, one of the bank’s longtime soldiers  Brian T. Moynihan  stood by ready and willing to take a job that others had turned down.

articles.headline: Hired by Customs, but Working for Mexican Cartels
articles.snippet: The authorities say drug traffickers, facing heightened border security, have stepped up efforts to corrupt agents.
articles.abstract: The authorities say drug traffickers, facing heightened border security, have stepped up efforts to corrupt agents.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO  At first, Luis F. Alarid seemed well on his way to becoming a customs agency success story. He had risen from a childhood of poverty and foster homes, some of them abusive, earned praise and commendations while serving in the Army and the Marines, including two tours in Iraq, and returned to Southern California to fulfill a goal of serving in law enforcement.

articles.headline: Questions on Security Mar Foreign Investments
articles.snippet: Foreign investors’ moves to buy U.S. industrial assets are getting a wary reaction from the Obama administration.
articles.abstract: Foreign investors’ moves to buy U.S. industrial assets are getting a wary reaction from the Obama administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As foreign investors once again try to buy American industrial assets, the Obama administration is grappling with how to protect national security while promoting economic recovery.

articles.headline: Google Said to Be Near a Yelp Deal
articles.snippet: In a sign that Google is interested in broadening its reach in the local business market, the search giant is in acquisition talks with Yelp, the review site for local businesses.
articles.abstract: In a sign that Google is interested in broadening its reach in the local business market, the search giant is in acquisition talks with Yelp, the review site for local businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Google is in discussions to buy Yelp, the Web site that lists and reviews local businesses, according to three people who had been briefed on the negotiations. The talks show how intently the biggest Web companies are setting their sights on the smallest neighborhood businesses, where they see a large and untapped group of advertisers.

articles.headline: G.M. Plans to Close Saab After Sales Talks Collapse
articles.snippet: Negotiations with Spyker Cars, a Dutch automaker, could not be completed by a Jan. 1 deadline, G.M. said.
articles.abstract: Negotiations with Spyker Cars, a Dutch automaker, could not be completed by a Jan. 1 deadline, G.M. said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saab, which earned a loyal following over six decades with its stylish but idiosyncratic cars, failed to attract the buyer it needed most  a new owner for the company  leaving General Motors little choice but to announce Friday that it would shut down the brand.
